Reviews.Title: Fujifilm 660EXR camera
Reviews.Author: Chuck
Reviews.Content: I read many reviews by customers on most all the pocket zoom cameras and this camera had pretty good reviews and many options on this camera. I am replacing an older Kodak digital camera.I have had it about 3 weeks and love it. It has a great zoom, wide angle, panarama, and the best of all the EXR feature which I feel is great for using the camera on fully automatic. You can also use many manual features with this camera if you wish.As far as the flash not poping up all the time, I feel that is a great feature. If I feel I need the flash, I can pop it up. I have read reviews on other cameras and the flash poping up every time you turn the camera on was a negative. If you are somewhere where you are not allowed to use a flash, you don't have to remember to close the flash or turn the flash off. If you don't pop it up manually, you don't have to worry about it going off. If you are taking pictures where you need or want to use the flash, when you turn off the camera, the flash retracts automatically.It also takes very good-excellent low light photographs.Very satisfied with no negatives. Battery life is as good as other pocket cameras.I also purchased the carry pouch (on Amazon)(great price) which also comes with a great little tripod for zoom shooting.Great camera!

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm FinePix F660EXR Review
Reviews.Author: Randy Wakeman "Randy Wakeman"
Reviews.Content: Fujifilm FinePix F660EXR Digital Camera ReviewThe travel zoom genre of cameras is of particular interest to me, personally. I've always found that the camera that you have with you takes far better pictures than the larger, bulkier unit you left at home, camp, or at the hotel. If it isn't convenient to carry around, I'm not interested, as I know that the wonderful images it might have taken won't exist.Digital cameras have been capable of taking quite enjoyable, pleasing images for a good long while. My "ancient" Canon PowerShot A610 (from 2005) boasted a 5 megapixel sensor, a 4x zoom, and had an articulated, fold-out 2 inch LCD along with an optical viewfinder. Seven years ago, it was considered good for 11 x 17 prints and included the novelty of capturing 640 x 480 (VGA) video. Power on to first shot from the made in China A610 is 1.4 seconds, and battery life is 27 hours of still-image capture mode with the LCD turned off, 11 hours of image playback with the LCD on. Retail in 2007 was $299, considered a bargain compared to the Canon A95 of a year prior that it replaced, that listed for about $400.  If you are wondering what the difference is between a great-looking 8 x 10 from 2007 and one from 2012 is, well, I'm wondering as well.Despite the impressive battery life from quad AA's, the A610 isn't readily pocketable. Its bulk and weight prohibit that. Digital cameras have rapidly advance, not always in a universally agreed upon good direction, but they have improved. In a prior round-up of digital camera for hunting and the outdoors,[...], the Canon SX230 came out on top. More recently, the Panasonic Lumix beat out the SX230 on the basis of fast shooting performance and a stunningly usable intelligent zoom of 37.9x. You can read the details at [...] .I've always felt that a review that compares something to something is more valuable than a stand-alone article. So, in this case the FujiFilm F660EXR is going up against the current champion of sorts, the Lumix ZS-15, with a few references to the very competent SX230HS Canon. It is, in my view, appropriate as both cameras have very similar zoom ranges, both are at very similar $200 - $230 street prices, and both are cameras that forgo the things that mean little to me, like a GPS, although both Fuji and Panasonic offer GPS versions at about a hundred dollar higher price premium.Zoom: The Fuji has a 15x optical zoom; the Lumix a 16x optical zoom. Both promise intelligent or smart digital zoom without severely impacting image quality.Battery Life: 300 shots CIPA standard for the Fuji, 260 shots for the Lumix. Extra batteries for the Fuji are almost ridiculously cheap as well.Battery Charging: Fuji supplies an external wall-charger, Panasonic is in-camera only as supplied. Advantage to Fuji out of the box, however wall-chargers are readily available for the ZS-15 albeit at extra cost.Weight / Size: The Fuji is slightly heavier (217g vs. 208g) but slightly smaller in envelope dimensions: 60x104x33mm vs. 61x105x34mm for the Lumix. No significant real-world difference, although the Fuji feels more secure in the hands.Sensor: Perhaps the most interesting part of the Fuji F660 is this "stage two" version of its back-side illuminated EXR sensor, a 1/2 inch (6.4 x 4.8 mm) sensor sporting a higher resolution (16MP) than the 12MP Panasonic sensor, and a bit larger size than the 1/2.3 inch Panasonic sensor as well. It is a bigger sensor, but even at approximately 15% increased size to a 1/2.3 it still rates as dinky. The "EXR" technology is a bit clumsy to explain, FujiFilm hardly makes it transparently clear, but the basic notion is that rather than a "16M" sensor, you have the effect of pixel doubling in 8M mode that either reduces noise substantially or extends the dynamic range substantially. The Panasonic sensor is the same as used on its larger Lumix FZ-150 "bridge camera." The same is true for the F660EXR, as apparently it is the same sensor is used on the larger HS-30EXR.LCD: Both the Fuji and the Panasonic have 460,000 dot three inch displays and both of them have brighter outdoor modes that can be engaged to combat direct sunlight. The Fuji rendition of this works better in the field.Video: Both cameras tout full HD; the Fuji adds specialty high speed modes at lower resolution. The Fuji has stereo mics, the Lumix has a monaural mic. The Fuji is essentially video on or off, while the Panasonic adds a very large number of features ported over from its still image capture options.Part of the confusion that runs rampant in digital cameras is the "MegaPixel Myth." Cameras are marketed and graded, by consumers anyway, in terms of megapixels alone. Often, it doesn't go much farther than that. Yet, megapixels don't tell the full tale. A small sensor camera might have 1.9 microns square photo sites, while a DSLR might offer 5.2 microns square photo sites. A full frame DSLR might have 8.24 microns square photo sites. This is why lower mega-pixel cameras with the same sensor size may well have better overall image quality. That is the case with the Panasonic Lumix ZS-15 (12.1 MP) vs. the allegedly a bit more upscale (in features) 14.1 MP Lumix ZS-20.How many megapixels do we need? Good question, as more than 300 dpi in color can't be readily used for printing, an 8 x 10 (2400 x 3000 pixels) is 7.2 MP. That might make sense, if we viewed 8 x 10 prints in a book, held between our hands. Often not the case, as framed photos on the wall are often enjoyed from five feet away. That changes things, as now 200 dpi is all that humans can discern. The A3 (11.7 x 16.5) print at 200 dpi is about 7.8 MP. This is why many of the framed 8 x 10 images on the wall I have produced are from 5 or "6 Meg" images (2816 x 2112) or thereabouts.So, that seems to be the theory behind the Fujifilm EXR pixel doubling sensor, or as they call it, "diagonally-aligned twin pixels of the same color." Like any marketing copy from any company, they can say most anything that sounds good, the actual results are what count. What the camera actually captures in 4:3 aspect ratio is size "L" (about 15.9 MP ) "M" (7.99 MP ) and "S" (3.98 MP). EXR sensors have three modes - high resolution, high signal to noise ratio, and high sensitivity. The "high resolution" is convention, whereas the half-resolution, 8 MP modes that are more interesting.I'll do my best to discuss how the Fuji F660EXR and the Panasonic ZS-15 compare, doing down the line for some of the most frequently discussed areas.PRICEAlthough the Fuji is listed with an abnormally high retail price (on Amazon at $379.99 list), that doesn't bear any scrutiny. You can buy it direct from the FujiFilm USA webstore for $279.99. You can buy the Panasonic direct from Panasonic for $249.99, so the "279.99 retail" makes little sense, either, but it is a lot closer to reality than the bombastic Fuji retail number. As I write this, the Fuji can be had for $209, the Panasonic for $205, so the street price is as close to the same as you're likely to find. In terms of value, the Fuji has an edge in two areas: a stand-alone wall charger is included (Lumix is USB in-camera only, taking the camera out of service) and extra batteries are surprisingly inexpensive. I paid $3.24 each, delivered, for "Kodak KLIC-7004 / Fuji Np-50 / Pentax DL-I68 Compatible Li-Ion Battery" presented as 3.7V, 1400 mAh, 5.18Wh, sold by eForCity.Panasonic is particularly irritating about suggesting you need their $35 "secure" battery to keep from going back in time or something, and their charger sells for  $16-- which should have been included in the box. You can do better, as in a Wasabi charger / two batteries Panasonic-compatible set from Blue Nook for $30, which is the path I took. Though we aren't talking much more than "Happy Meal" funding, the Fuji does rate as a better value... if it turns out to be the camera you want.VIDEOBoth the F660EXR and the Panasonic ZS-15 are capable of HD video capture. However, both the monaural audio of the ZS-15 and the stereo mics of the Fuji pick up motor noise when zooming, as do most compacts inclusive of the Canon SX230. The difference between stereo and mono audio exists primarily on a specifications sheet. The mics are so very, very tiny no high quality is to be expected and no great stereo separation is possible, either.For stationary video capture, either might be considered adequate, but rank clear notch below any number of inexpensive camcorders that cost no more than these compact still cameras. The Fuji has a couple of fun slow-motion modes, although at lower resolution, to experiment with in bright light. They are 640 x 480 at 80 fps, 320 x 240 at 120 fps, and a tiny 320 x 112 at 320 fps. The Fuji movie mode is essentially one way, the automatic way. One thing you can do is lose the "continuous focus" (the focus drifts during zoom and the camera transmits focusing noise) and go with "center focus" for more consistent but still unremarkable results. Aside from the high speed modes, the F660EXR has very little to offer for video. A hint of this is the video record page in the owner's manual that is just that, one skimpy page. The biggest issue with the Fuji is the sluggish focusing in movie mode. Combined with what seems to be no image stabilization at all, it is apparent that FujiFilm added video capability as an afterthought and with very little attention. Regardless of its "HD" capture, out of focus and jerky video isn't a pretty picture. It is tripod only and easy on the zoom for enjoyable results and is the biggest failing of the F660. The video it captures is very dark so as to be nearly worthless indoors. I consider it a last resort feature, at best.On the other hand, the Lumix ZS-15 has a boatload of features that are ported over to its video function including all ten creative modes, many of the scene modes, etc. In the "Intelligent Auto" mode, you can even intelligent zoom your way to 32x in the 720p mode I generally shoot in, while the creative modes are 16x. While video and compact digital cameras don't always get along well, there is no question that if video is important to you, the Panasonic gives you more far options, more control, more features, and overall far better quality moving pictures.SMART ZOOM / INTELLIGENT ZOOMFuji calls their version "intelligent zoom" while Panasonic calls their version "intelligent zoom" as well. Sony used to call their rendition "smart zoom" but now apparently it is "clear zoom." The basic idea is this: when shooting at full resolution of a compact camera, digital zoom interpolates part of the image, manufacturing an image that generally turns people into nuclear holocaust victims or similar. However, when shooting at half resolution of the sensor, no digital pixelization  type interpolation occurs. Instead, you frame your image as usual and you get a print-ready image with no fuss, at half the native resolution of the sensor. While I hesitate to call it as good as straight optical, it is very good and nets you a 30x image when 15x won't do, and the cropping of a bloated 16M image leaves you with the portion you really wanted a bit out of focus. Just as important, you have a good representation of the image on your 3 inch LCD when you actually take the shot. Grabbing a huge image and crop might sound good, but exactly what a small crop might turn out to be when you hit the button is not easy to discern. They both work well and equally well that I can discern.LOW LIGHTThere is no universally accepted notion of low light. After all, most compact digital cameras have a built-in flash. The Panasonic flash unit is integral on the body, rated at 0.6 - 6.4m (Wide/ISO Auto), 1.0 - 3.5m (Tele/ISO Auto). The Fuji "Super Intelligent Flash," a pop-up unit, is rated at 15 cm - 3.2 meters for wide angle, 90 cm - 1.9 meters for telephoto. While you might think a pop-up flash to be more powerful, I'd normally assume that as well, the Fuji has similar specs to the Canon SX230 and it is actually the Panasonic with a flash that has about twice the effective range of either of them.In the case of low-light, sans flash, which is my version of low-light anyway, neither of these cameras have fast lens arrays or large sensors, the normal prescription for excellent low light captures. The Canon SX230 has an often wondrous handheld night mode, which composites two pictures quickly. The Panasonic has the same mode, but the results aren't nearly as good.The Fuji has the largest number of options to choose from without resorting to a tripod, though it has that night mode as well. You can go with the auto EXR mode, which often hits the "High ISO Low Noise" sensor function, but varies with the individual scene. Or, you can direct the camera to go straight there with the EXR Priority mode. Or, you can go to the "Pro Low-Light" mode that takes four images and combines them. Further, you can set the camera to save the original images, so you'll have your four originals that you can consider later in addition to the "Pro Low-Light" composite. The "save original" also applies to the auto panorama, red-eye removal, and "Pro Focus" modes as well. If that wasn't enough, there are more low-light options in the scene position arena to choose from: "Natural & Flash, Natural, Night, and Night Tripod." The Fujifilm F660EXR handily wins the low light award (when shooting at 1/2 resolution), though the exact mode that does it for you will take some personal experimentation contingent on the precise scene you are capturing. It is the best low-light compact long zoom I've tested.LCD DISPLAYBoth the Fuji and the Panasonic have upgraded (to these respective newer models) 460,000 dot 3 inch 4:3 aspect ratio displays. Both have "power" modes to mitigate the frustrating effect of direct sun washout, the Panasonic is dubbed "Power LCD." Fuji calls their feature the "Monitor Sunlight Mode."  They are both effective but the Fuji F660 display is more usable in bright, direct sunlight.HANDLINGThe Fuji has a better, more secure feel in the hands due to its textured grip on the right side and some effective little rubber nubs for your thumb on the back of the unit. The Fujifilm F660EXR also has a more readily accessible video button. However, the Panasonic mode dial isn't quite as easily inadvertently knocked into a different mode as the easier to spin Fuji dial can be, but the Fuji placement is more convenient. Overall, the Fuji is a bit better feeling and more stable when shooting.SPEEDThe Panasonic is generally peppier in operation, but the Fuji is in the same arena, feeling a bit faster switching from capture mode to review mode. It is very quick to go from image capture to image review with the push of a button or shutter on the Fuji, while Panasonic still has the slower mechanical slide to change over. In normal operation, 8M files are being saved in the Fuji, whereas 5M files are saved in the Panasonic. Both are quite sufficient for 8 x 10 prints. Your choice in the Panasonic, in 4:3 aspect ratio, is between 12M and 5M, though there are more aspect ratios to select from. With the Fuji, it is "L" (16M) or "M" (8M) in 4:3, the M mode is where you'll want it, as that is what allows the EXR sensor to change between the three possible modes. The Fuji "S" (4M) mode, 2304 x 1728, would be for snapshot or web use, primarily, or perhaps insertion into a video production.STILL PICTURE FEATURESBoth cameras have auto panorama modes, the Fuji adds double exposure capability so you can create superimposed images. Fuji has standard, soft, vivid, black & white, and sepia modes. Panasonic counters with similar modes, calling their vivid mode "Happy." Panasonic fills out the soft, black & white, and sepia options, adding "expressive," retro, high key, low key, toy, miniature, and high dynamic to experiment with. Both cameras have automatic face detection, Fuji adds face detection for dogs and cats as well. Both have 3D modes, though I find little value in them.There is "exposure bracketing" with the Panasonic, where three pictures are taken and you adjust the exposure based on your selection of one of the three. Your selection then becomes the default exposure. Fuji goes quite a bit farther. In addition to the three shot exposure bracket burst which saves three images for you, one standard, one underexposed, and one overexposed according to the default, the F660 gives you the three image "bracketing option" on color and dynamic range as well. One push of the button, you have three images in "Provia (std.), Velvia (Vivid), and Astia (soft). Later, you can decide which of these three film simulation mode captures appeals to you the most. Fuji does the same for Dynamic Range as well: one push of the button, three images to choose from. It is the image superimposing ability, large number of low light modes, and the three-way exposure / film mode / dynamic range bracketing that combine to give the Fuji the solid edge in the still images features department.Conclusion:The Fuji has the ***worst*** video capability of any compact I've tested. It is really horrid and an embarrassment considering how good the rest of the camera works. If taking video with your digital still camera is important to you, this glaring defect alone will be more than sufficient for you to go elsewhere. I'll leave it to you to grade the importance of the video in your own terms.However, the Fuji F660EXR is sold as a digital still camera, not as a camcorder that can take stills. As a digital camera, it handles better than the Panasonic (and the Canon SX230 for that matter), puts them both to shame in terms of battery life, many still camera features, and in particular low light ("M" or 8M mode). When viewed and used as an "8MP" camera, the captured images from the Fuji are 3264 x 2448. That's more than adequate for an outstanding 8 x 10 print even with a moderate amount of cropping. It is also better than needed for very good prints up to 20 x 30, according to most. As tragic as the video attempt is on the F660EXR, it easily rates as a good choice in a long zoom digital still camera, with exemplary low light capabilities for the platform. The included charger and inexpensive batteries, along with a $210 street price make it a very compelling compact travel zoom still camera.At the same time, the Panasonic yields more consistent results: a higher percentage of pictures are crisp and blur-free with the ZS-15. The just plain lousy video ability of the Fuji is not as advertised or as described by Fuji or by Amazon. Overall the Panasonic is a far more satisfying camera, despite the better handling of the Fuji.Copyright June, 2012 by Randy Wakeman and Randy Wakeman Outdoors. All Rights Reserved.

Reviews.Title: Great camera - great price
Reviews.Author: P. Sites "birdnut"
Reviews.Content: I've had this camera three weeks now, and I really love it.  It replaced an F300exr, and this one is an improvement, from the fact that the flash doesn't pop up when you turn it on, to the fast start-up and re-cycling, to the accurate colors and depth in the photos.  The pro-focus and pro-low light modes help create great photos, and the 5 film-simulation modes are fun to work with.  It's small to tuck away, fun and powerful to use, and at a great price point.  I didn't need all the bells and whistles of the F750 or F770, and I'm glad Fuji made this "in-between" camera with such great features at such a good price.

Reviews.Title: GREAT CAMERA - PERFECT for EBAY SELLERS & MORE!
Reviews.Author: Rosie from Portland Oregon
Reviews.Content: I just love FUJI Cameras .. I am a Veteran Ebay Seller & that requires alot of Photos to be taken for my Listings. This Camera is Fabulous .. Lots of Bells & Whistles too numerous to mention. I Like the the option to adjust the ISO settings making it easy NOT to have to use your Flash so much on indoor shots. The Macro option is Nice, great Close-Ups for those little Collectibles. Other Options built in include Image Quality, Crop & Resize features, even image rotation too. Among ALL the Fabulous Features it even has CAT & DOG Face Recognition! :) I take thousands of Photos & the thing I noitce the Most is HOW FAST it is compared to my old 12 year old Fuji which just started Giving me problems. IF THIS Camera Lasts as Long.. it's the Deal of the Century!IF you are a Ebay Seller or Have a Website.. THIS IS A GREAT Moderately Price Fuji! I also purchase a additional Bundle/kit which included 2 extra Batteries, Battery Charger, window screen protecters.

Reviews.Title: Tops for its type.
Reviews.Author: A Customer
Reviews.Content: Reviews of cameras are dominated by comparisons, personal preferences and opinions. I'm no different in this respect because I look for certain features, the Fujifilm 660 being my ninth digital camera.  I chose the 660 for these features: - The EXR sensor - Zoom beyond 4X - Fast focus - Shutter,aperture and manual shooting modes - No GPS - Ability to use at 8MP - At least 4fps burst mode - Flash normally off - Relatively inexpensive battery - Bright LCD - F-Button quick menuThis meets my needs almost perfectly!But alas, I cannot use it because it has NO VIEWFINDER and without it I cannot control action shots nor high-zoom shots without carrying a tripod with the camera.  And this alone defeats the purpose of having a pocketable photo device.  Otherwise the 660 is an excellent camera.  (I currently have three other cameras, all with viewfinders)

Reviews.Title: low quality pics high quality video
Reviews.Author: Snitch
Reviews.Content: hello.i'll start from photo shooting.i had about 10 point and shoot cameras under 180$, and i never seen before faster auto focus. (1 star for this), when half pressing on shoot button. macro mode is very good.biggest problem of this camera is very bad iso balance. thats using very high iso on auto iso mode. in little room with flash  about 800 and pictures are very noised. in sunlight useing 400-640-800 and picture quality is same. of course you can set ISO manualy but anyway pictures are poor quality. i'm very dissapointed in this camera.video is very good. sensor shift IS works great but if you changing distance recording focusing on different object is very low speed. high speed recording is great. 1 star for video recordingand design. its very nice and very comfartable feeling in hand. 1 star for thisif you want good camera with big zoom and with good price i'll recomended CANON SX130 SX150 SX160but like video recorder this camera is great.  thank you very much

Reviews.Title: Lens cover will not fully close or open
Reviews.Author: Toby L "tobyl37"
Reviews.Content: The lense cover has a number of shutters that are supposed to close and open together. It worked properly for awhile but then partially jammed.Camera was sent to Fuji for repairs and returned after several weeks. It worked for awhile but then jammed again. I suggest purchasing a camera with a better closure system.

Reviews.Title: Grrrrreat camera!
Reviews.Author: Malissia Simpson
Reviews.Content: I'm a Nikon girl.  With some trepidation, I purchased this camera on the advice of a friendly, local camera store salesman.  I did my research before purchase and discovered that this camera has many features that are on $1500-$2000 cameras.  I usually spend that much or more on cameras because I am a photographer and am very picky about the equipment I buy.  However, I'm tired of lugging around heavy equipment and have been looking for something that had all the bells and whistles yet was compact and easy to carry.  This is it.  Not only that, but the price I paid versus the price in the camera store made the choice much easier.  It would have cost me over $100 more to receive exactly the same thing.  Why pay more when there's Amazon.  There is a small learning curve because this camera can do sooo many things, but if you can read and follow instructions, purchase this camera.

Reviews.Title: I wanted to like it
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "tamme"
Reviews.Content: The zoom was so loud when I was filming using the video feature that I just couldn't keep it. It was small still shots were good.

Reviews.Title: great for the price
Reviews.Author: Craig "I'm Lovin It"
Reviews.Content: Takes wonderful pictures and is fairly quick on the trigger.  We have a larger slr camera that takes more time in focusing, we wanted something we can turn on and snap a picture.  2 little ones in the house and want to catch those special moments, wouldn't be able to do it with the bigger camera, but this one...works good.

Reviews.Title: Spectacular!!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: For the price, this camera is a steal!! It takes wonderful pictures that are clear and crisp! The photos are also at extremely high pixels too which is nice.

Reviews.Title: Night shots
Reviews.Author: Happy photographer
Reviews.Content: Just got my 660 today and i am amazed at what this camera does. I like to take sunset and night pictures.I put it on the special scene mode and the pictures are perfect. fuji put fun back in taking pictures!

Reviews.Title: more than expected
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: This more than met my expectations.  A head of schedule arrival.  New product.  Works great. Happy with company and product.

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm F660 exr
Reviews.Author: sgt358
Reviews.Content: This is one of several digital cameras that I have owned. After quite a bit of research, I decided to purchase the F660 exr. I'm very glad I did. It has many functions and all work as advertised. It is a steal at the price Amazon charges. If you're looking for a great digital camera, look no further.

Reviews.Title: F660 Camera Great
Reviews.Author: johnb
Reviews.Content: This FUJIFILM Exr F660 camera is just super. Much better than carrying a much larger camera that the batteries didn't last as long with and always seemed like I didn't have on me when I wanted to take a picture when traveling. Also the 15x optical lens is nice to have on a compact camera. Price was also unbeatable and delivered on time.

Reviews.Title: Great but one really annoying issue
Reviews.Author: pexring
Reviews.Content: I love everything about this camera except one really annoying issue that almost caused me to return it.  The slanted dial on the top moves very easily.  Almost impossible to take in and out of a pocket and not have that dial move.  Many good pictures have been lost because the dial too easily moved to another setting.  Otherwise the camera is great.  I like the fact that I control when the flash pops up.  It's quick and the pictures are sharp if lighting is fairly normal.  Abnormal lighting like shooting in trees isn't so great, but that would be tricky for a lot of cameras.

Reviews.Title: So far, so good
Reviews.Author: D. Guio "dwguio"
Reviews.Content: Just a couple of month's use and, so far, the camera is operating well.Pro:  size and weight, excellent wide angle shots, flash works well, quick light metering, VERY fast and easy uploads to my computer and Picasa using the supplied cable, good battery life, has a quality feel to it.Con:  Miniscule 'starter' owners manual included, forcing you to either scroll/read online or print 100+ pages at my expense.  Slanted rotary function select dial has ergonomic slant - but is too easy to accidentally move settings when stowing in pocket or purse. Every time you must check to see if it's been changed by accident.  Don't like the spring-loaded door to insert the usb cable - feels flimsy and just waiting to break.

Reviews.Title: amazing value
Reviews.Author: Darius Keith "old dandy"
Reviews.Content: I'VE BEEN AN AVID PHOTOGRAPHER AND EARNED MY LIVING WITH A CAMERA FOR EIGHT YEARS. BOUGHT THIS CAMERA FOR MY "DOCUMENTOR" WIFE TO REPLACE HER OLD FUJI EXR. AMAZING VALUE IN A POCKETABLE DIGITAL! ONLY DOWNFALL, (AS USUAL), IS THE LACK OF AN OPTICAL VIEWFINDER. THESE LITTLE GEMS CAN NEVER BE A "REAL CAMERA" WITHOUT AN ACCURATE MEANS OF COMPOSING THE PHOTOGRAPH.

Reviews.Title: Everything is top notch - except picture quality
Reviews.Author: Sniper Fan
Reviews.Content: I just opened the package and tried the camera. Everything other reviewers and the marketing hypes might wow for is justified - tons of features, settings, bells and whistles are there, sturdy build, handy size, shiny display with zillions of icons, easy to use menus and so on... but the picture qualitiy is far inferior to my 9 years old Finepix S5000 (set to 3MP resolution), let alone the price tag. No matter which size, setting, resolution and effect you choose, the images are foggy, blurry, kind of "washed out", total lack of detail, like an old postcard. If you happy to buy a camera for it's features, buttons, beeps and dials, this one's definitely for you, but if you want to have crisp and detailed pictures - don't buy it.

Reviews.Title: Wouldn't purchase again.  Sony is much easier to use, unfortunately Sony is horrible for night time pics.
Reviews.Author: Sheryl Mary
Reviews.Content: Camera is awkward to use.  It takes a lot of flipping back and forth to get the right settings, settings within settings.  Only some settings give a clear picture, even in daylight.  Still haven't found the right one to use consistently.

Reviews.Title: Power button stop working !
Reviews.Author: kenneth borrego
Reviews.Content: After the fourth time of using this camera, the power would not come on. The battery was just fully charged. Needless to say, I am very disappointed. Now I need to pack it back in the box and figure out how and where to return it and get a refund.

Reviews.Title: A great multipurpose camera
Reviews.Author: ChuckG
Reviews.Content: I really like this camera, for several reasons. I like that it powers up quickly and that it has no delay for shutter release when I push the button. I also find that I use the panorama mode more than expected, so that's a great feature. The zoom is plenty long enough, and I have no problems with its shutter speed. It has a lot of various modes which I may never use, like firework or dog mode, but we'll see.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera for the price
Reviews.Author: BLRGFTN
Reviews.Content: Takes a great picture from such a small camera. This model is improved from the F550 in that the flash doesn't automatically come up now when it is turned on.

Reviews.Title: good value for the money
Reviews.Author: carol chamberlain
Reviews.Content: Camera nice size just learning to use. So far seems real easy.  Real happy with the low light feature. Cant wait to use it on our upcoming river cruise. I think the panaroma feature is going to be great .

Reviews.Title: 5 stars
Reviews.Author: Gary Scott
Reviews.Content: The camera is superb with all the features I wanted.  Outstanding focus even on zoom shots.  And after some trial and error very easy to use.

Reviews.Title: Love it
Reviews.Author: Natasha Martinez
Reviews.Content: I am really happy with this camera the picture quality is pretty awesome. I went on a trip to Alaska and Canada and I was able to get pictures of the animals even if they were far away they looked a lot closer then what they were in the pictures, so I was really happy with the zoom. There are also so many different settings so you have the right type of lighting or flash you need for whatever situation you are in. The video quality of the camera isn't the greatest, but if I wanted great video I would buy a video camera, so if you want it for video quality I wouldn't invest in it but for pictures it's awesome. Compared it to my mom, sisters, and brother in laws camera and this one took better pictures then theirs.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for every day user
Reviews.Author: D. Buffenbarger "Buff"
Reviews.Content: Had to find a camera, inexpensive, long zoom for taking pictures rapidly.  Results are very good with details and nice color balance.  Decent flexibility in settings for a point and shoot camera.  Sometimes colors are not as vivid as real life.  I would buy it again for general picture taking.

Reviews.Title: I like it
Reviews.Author: Bobby E Lucas
Reviews.Content: Excellent product, takes excellent pictures, on automatic setting it adjusts to all kinds of conditions, grate features, screen nice and large for this size camera, will buy shipped on time.

Reviews.Title: Good zoom, great bargain
Reviews.Author: Retired Tire Engineer "Drew"
Reviews.Content: I ran across this camera on the Amazon web site looking for a pocket-able ultrazoom.  I was concerned that the lens might not be up to the 16 megapixel sensor, but it seems to be very sharp.  1080P HD video is nice, but I'm also looking forward to playing with the 320 frames per second low res video.  The thing to be aware of is that, even with a CMOS sensor, the noise levels go up fairly rapidly with increases in ISO. An ISO of about 400 is about as high as you would want to go if you are planning to do some cropping.  Battery life appears to be quite good also.  For the price (~ $116) you can't beat this camera.

Reviews.Title: First blush ...excellent
Reviews.Author: Roger W. Alswager "Alswager"
Reviews.Content: First ....hats off to Amazon ...and PRIME ...I ordered this camera on Wednesday night ...actually late enough to register as Thursday ...and I received it today(Friday)!  Great service.Charged the battery, put it and the 8gb class 10 Transcend memory card I bought along with it ...set the dial to EXR snapped a dozen pictures ...flipped it to P and forced flash and snapped another dozen.  Viewed the pictures in the camera, on the computer and online.  Results are amazing for a $138 camera.This is a bargain camera yielding excellent results for anyone that wants to upgrade from an unsophisticated point and shoot.  It will allow full control for those that want and know how to use it.  I bought and returned an Olympus XZ-1 because of inconsistent results with flash and auto exposure modes.  (It was  apparent within the same amount of limited shooting as I tried with the F660EXR) .. I then bought a Panasonic DMC-LX7 and love it.  This for $138 ...(assuming no reliability issues) is not that far off the results with the Panasonic.  I chose this over the Samsung WB150F because a friend has one that I tried and I was not that fond of the picture quality and have no need for WIFI.  This is NOT a high priced DSLR or a $600 mirror-less system camera so don't expect Louvre quality prints ....but if you are contemplating a $100-ish point and shoot, I would highly recommend you consider this camera ....given it's quality, size and amazing price.PS ....it also comes with a charger ...which is an optional accessory for the Samsung

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Jane Jetley "erajane"
Reviews.Content: This camera is just what I was looking for.I has all the bells and whistles I wanted at anaffordable price.Have not figured out all the settings and options.

Reviews.Title: GOOD camera: MY Mistake: NOT Out-of-focus zoom, color too yellow
Reviews.Author: Fiction Fan "lifelong reader"
Reviews.Content: One day later...I realized I wasn't using the camera correctly. There's nothing wrong with the camera--it was user error. I'm revising my rating and apologize for giving it such a poor rating in the first place.I received this camera last night and was eager to try it out. What a disappointment to discover that zooming in on an object (cat) just 15 feet away would result in a very blurry, out-of-focus photo. Indoor shots were marked by bad color, as well--they all had a markedly yellow cast to them. I tried various features to correct these issues, but without success. I am returning the camera.

Reviews.Title: i'm too old for this
Reviews.Author: H. ivanow "francophile"
Reviews.Content: it is too complicated for a 'computer challenged' person of my age.  way, way too many choices for settings.  will never learn them.  camera will break before i find the proper setting for outside and/or inside pix taking... but i do say, it has a lot of potentially good things, like the panoramic setting, the instand video which records in MOV format - many computers are not able to open this type of files.  i do like the battery storage, which i see will not break like the AA using cameras.  but get yourself another spare battery:  the flash absorbs the juice... fast!  beside the complicity of the camera, i do give it a 4 star.

Reviews.Title: good, solid camera
Reviews.Author: jason santucci
Reviews.Content: I've had this now for about 6 months and so far, I am more than pleased with the photos this camera takes.  The zoom works great for both photos and movies.  I'm a professional photographer and this is my "always have camera" because it' compact and fits in my pocket so I don't have to haul all my gear out sometimes on ski trips and long mountain bike rides.,

Reviews.Title: Pretty good, with some flaws.
Reviews.Author: predatorycircuit
Reviews.Content: Overall the camera is pretty good. The picture quality is excellent, build quality is good, and audio is above average. Butttt the low light performance is below sub par, so watch out for that.

Reviews.Title: The Camera
Reviews.Author: Dominique Watson
Reviews.Content: I don't have much to say only that I got it on time and was able to give it as a gift. From what I can see the person that received  it is quite happy with it, and is creating beautiful pictures.

Reviews.Title: Good pictures but with a little black point in all the pictures
Reviews.Author: Ruben Montero
Reviews.Content: The camera takes great photos but has a problem in all the photos get a black, small point, but it is well visible. If I could send a photo would do it for you to see. The problem is that I am in Venezuela and return from here can be as expensive as the price of the camera. Not that you could do for me in relation to the operation of the camera. I bought it sent it to the address of a family and I recently brought it a week ago.

Reviews.Title: Not sharp enough
Reviews.Author: Richard Leon "JC Cliffhanger"
Reviews.Content: Just returned this after trying to take some indoor pictures. The exposure compensation did nothing at first even in program so checked the manual and it should have worked....well after awhile of shooting it started working. The battery started dying right away and then the indicator went from half to full again. Too many glitches, but the bottom line is that the pictures were not sharp. Too soft and for 129 dollars I am not surprised. So I went to the Imaging Resource site  and used their Comparometer to compare real photographs of identical setups with a variety of cameras. I used my Nikon p7700 as a base and the Sony WX-300 came the closest in the pocket style camera. You can find it here for $229 and it has a 20x zoom. But its the sharpness of the pictures that sold me.

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera
Reviews.Author: C. Welter
Reviews.Content: This camera takes super pix and its easy to use . The size is small enough to carry in pockets or bags but its a nice size for holding on to while using it. I would recommend this camera ... It has plenty of features for the more experienced photographer but its easy to just point and shoot too.

Reviews.Title: Good substitute for SLR
Reviews.Author: craig spiering
Reviews.Content: I don't like carrying my SLR on long flights or hikes so this is a very nice pocket style camera.  Compact,  with good zoom, wide angle and some other decent manual options including f-stop changes and variable shutter speeds, it's a good substitute.  I'm concerned about durability since my first camera broke down after about 2 years; but Fuji replaced it free of charge.

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm Fine Pix Meets Expectations
Reviews.Author: Sara L. Jennings
Reviews.Content: This is a great little camera.  Sharp as a tack photos, easy to use and carry and the price is right

Reviews.Title: Amazing picture quality
Reviews.Author: Abhishek Jaiswal
Reviews.Content: The picture quality is amazing. I have just had it for about a day but I ALREADY LOVE THE CRISPNESS OF THE PICTURES.

Reviews.Title: first one did not work
Reviews.Author: Carolyn M Shields
Reviews.Content: I actually love this camera.  The first one did not work. Was going to S America so returned it and bought a second which is great. I did have to pay express shipping twice, but the reimbursement for the first one was smooth.

Reviews.Title: Good build quality, images not so much.
Reviews.Author: Double U Gee
Reviews.Content: I was looking forward to using this camera as the size is great for travel and some of the built-in features seemed really cool. I took the camera out for a shooting session next to my 6MP Nikon D40. One would expect fairly similar results, if not better images from the newer Fujifilm camera with newer sensor, etc. The F660 images were very blurry at the edges of the frame at all focal lengths. The images were very flat with not much contrast between shadows and bright light. I can't say that the images from the F660 were much better than those from my Android cell phone.

Reviews.Title: A bargain deal
Reviews.Author: Taranome
Reviews.Content: This camera is a fancy snapshot camera--not a professional tool.  It has many options from slow motion video to close ups with blurred back ground to help you get what you like.  The ergonomics are fine for me, though the mode dial is a bit too easy to turn by accident--but the mode is shown on the screen, so it's easy to notice and correct.  The camera feels nice and sturdy, and it's nice and quick to turn on and has very little shutter delay.  The EXR mode works very well in most situations and that's mainly what I use.  The results are fairly sharp and have good color.  For the price, I think this is one of the best deals around--it's an older model, so if you want one don't wait too long.

Reviews.Title: Very good overall
Reviews.Author: tvp81
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to take pictures of my newborn baby, and I'm very happy with it.  I get good, useable photos consistently despite his constant squirming.  The EXR mode is very helpful for someone like me (not an avid photographer, don't have time to read the manual).  The compact size and long battery life are other pluses.  The video feature is pretty good; at times it records a slightly annoying clicking sound in the background.  Overall, I would recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: LOVE!
Reviews.Author: Alex
Reviews.Content: I absolutely LOVE this camera. I bought it for when I go on trips. It takes better pictures than my friend's huge expensive camera. It's light, you can take it anywhere, it's stylish. I named mine Blake. I absolutely, positively would recommend this camera to anyone.

Reviews.Title: Doesn't live up to the Fujifilm name
Reviews.Author: Alexandra Weiss
Reviews.Content: As a previous Fujifilm camera owner I expected the newer model of the EXR to work just as well as my older model, if not better. I am extremely disappointed with this camera. Over 50% of my pictures turn our blurry. We read the owners manual and kept thinking that it might be a user error. But after a month of playing with the camera our pictures are still not turning out right. I would not recommend this camera to anyone. The 550 EXR is a MUCH better model.

Reviews.Title: Longtime FinePix F-Series Fan... No Longer!
Reviews.Author: lbp2488
Reviews.Content: I was very disappointed with this camera. It had a lens flare that made it impossible to take clear, vibrant, or crisp pictures in daylight, period-- cloudy or sunny. I took it on vacation, and thankfully I brought my iPhone along, too, and also took pictures with that. If I'd only had the F660 on the trip, I would've come back with almost nothing usable.Inspired by using my brother's FinePix F10 back in 2006, I've owned an F30 and F41fd, and I really wanted this camera to measure up at least partially, but it didn't come close. Most of my pictures look like they were taken with a foggy lens, and I assure you, it was totally clean, both inside and out. I even took it to a camera shop for advice on why my pictures looked so foggy, and they said it was just a lens flare issue. That didn't quite explain why the right side of every image was also always blurry, but oh well.I returned the camera as soon as I got home and purchased the Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS19 instead (my boyfriend had the ZS20 on the trip, and his pictures were gorgeous).

Reviews.Title: Fuji EXR 600 Camera
Reviews.Author: Joseph Caruso
Reviews.Content: Takes good pictures overall but you have to manually pop up the flash which I find annoying. It should pop up automatically when needed in low light.  Also the battery life is not that great. Otherwise its take great pictures and videos.

Reviews.Title: Not too bad.
Reviews.Author: Maria Lane
Reviews.Content: I chose this camera to replace an old one that got stolen.  I LOVED my old camera...  I figured hey a newer model??  May not be the most updated on the market but it can't be bad....  Well....  This comera does not have an automatic flash....  You have to hit a button on the side to get the light to actually pop up.  The old camera I had did it automatically.  It's a shame that the site doesn't have more detailed pictures or a better summary of the product.  When in a rush to take a picture of something it's a pain to remember you have to hit an extra button for something that should be automatic..... especially on a newer model than what I had.

Reviews.Title: good
Reviews.Author: Robert Tator
Reviews.Content: I have used for a few months so far. There are a lot of settings for the "pros". As I only take a few pictures, I only use a few settings.So far, good. The battery lasts a lot better than my other camera that used AA batteries.

Reviews.Title: I like the camera and the features...but
Reviews.Author: G-bury
Reviews.Content: One drop and the screen is dead.  We are sending it back to be replaced, but I'm not sure how much it will cost.  Probably more than the camera! Hopefully not.  The camera is fast and takes great photos though.  I especially like the slow motion feature on the video mode.  Pitty it was so fragile though.

Reviews.Title: Toally Disappointed
Reviews.Author: T. Pham
Reviews.Content: The good: really compact,good zoom, decent quality, easily fit in your pocket for travelling,The bad: worked well for one year then stopped:Could not auto focus. Looked into the manual and it says you better bring it for repair and with the price coming down it's not worth to have it fixed. The sad part is I am Fujifilm camera fan for so many years!

Reviews.Title: Worst Camera I have ever owned.
Reviews.Author: Charlotte Kirkpatrick
Reviews.Content: All my pictures come out blurred and unusable. I have reading the instruction book, I have taken it to two professional photographer and I still cannot figure out how to fix setting to make my pictures clear. Last resort . . . I'm going to try calling the manufacture and see if the camera is faulty. Note: The first camera I received did not work at all, this is the replacement one and it does not seem to work either. Do not buy this camera

Reviews.Title: Missing photo taking feautures
Reviews.Author: Speed Racer
Reviews.Content: This is a camera rich in specs and feautures  many do not show up on their menus. Forget about AE Bracketing and the others that should be there as well.  Toobad, for the lens and zoom are very good. Also I can not reach any support tech.

Reviews.Title: Poor 3D feature
Reviews.Author: RAB "RAB"
Reviews.Content: I'm an owner of a Fuji F300, which is a predecessor of the F660. So I bought the F660 mostly because of its 3D feature. Unfortunately, its 3D feature does not play directly from the Camera to our LG 3D TV, which works with 3D output from the Fuji W3 and various Sony cameras, instead requires special Fuji software and ideally a Fuji player. However, the show-stopper with this camera was that it almost never focussed sharply at longest zoom, unlike the Fuji F300 that never had such a problem. Returned for refund, will wait for improved camera.

Reviews.Title: Not worth to buy
Reviews.Author: AL AMIN
Reviews.Content: I have recently had to return this camera, The Zoom was great however zooming while recording video created lot of blurs, Pictures at auto settings had a lot of grains, most of the time auto settings picks higher ISO thus pictures come so noisy that you can't crop and get a decent quality picture despite of the high resolution. I will strongly recommend not to by this piece of crap. The video quality is very bad compared to samsung WB750 that I bought earlier could record crystal clear voice and video.(However, I returned the samsung wb750 thinking better products are available, however now I regret, because they have increased the price of wb750 now).

Reviews.Title: Lottery??
Reviews.Author: Allan Hawkins V
Reviews.Content: First Amazon page said 129.99 and when yoy go to product page you will find 149.00. Seems to be nothing profesional!

Reviews.Title: Wow
Reviews.Author: Better than McCarthy
Reviews.Content: I needed a camera for a family occasion to stand in for my Nikon 9100, which was getting repaired.  This was about the cheapest I could find, and fully expected to return it at the end of the family visit.  Then I began to use the little thing and looked at the results.  Excellent!  The Nikon is back now, but the Fuji is staying.

Reviews.Title: So far I'm very happy with my FinePix F660EXR
Reviews.Author: Svavar O. Svavarsson
Reviews.Content: I got this to replace my FinePix F100FD. I've been a fan of the FinePix line for years and this camera lives up to my expectations.I've only had it for a few days and haven't explored everything it has to offer but so far it's been great. I'll be updating this review once I've used the camera more.

ProductInfo.Features:
16MP 1/2 inch EXR CMOS Sensor
High Quality Fujinon 15x Optical Zoom Lens
3.0 inches LCD
Full HD Movies
High Speed Continuous Shooting
ProductInfo.Name: Fujifilm FinePix F660EXR Digital Camera
